result.execSummary:
The defendant Quinard M Jackson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • 2nd-Degree Recklessly Endangering Safety [Modifiers: Use of a Dangerous Weapon], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 941.30(2).
  • Intimidate Witness/Threaten Force, etc., a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.43(3).
  • Intimidate Witness/Threaten Force, etc., a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.43(3).
  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Per Clerk's conversation with Judge Brantmeier the Court Orders the statutory costs of Count #1 & #4 in case 18CF14 be converted to civil judgments.

[MA]Cases 15CF237, 15CF271, and 18CF14 called together at 2:58pm 
Defendant Quinard M Jackson in court, in custody with Attorney Jessica A Klein.  DA Susan Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

As to Cases 15CF237 and 15CF271, Sentencing Hearing on Revocation occurs: 
--The Court verifies review of sentencing transcript and revocation packet

As to Case 18CF14, Plea & Sentencing occurs:   
Maximum penalties recited; Constitutional rights reviewed; plea of " NO CONTEST " entered on Counts #1 and #4; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified.  The Court accepts the plea, finds the Defendant guilty, and orders Judgment of Conviction entered.

Sentencing arguments given by DA Happ
Sentencing arguments given by Attorney Klein
Statement made by Mr. Jackson

On Motion of the State, the Court reads in Counts #2 and #3 of Case 18CF14

As to Case 18CF14, Counts #1 and #4: The Court sentences Defendant to:
--serve 8 months  in Jefferson County Jail, as to each count, concurent to each other with Huber privileges; to commence FORTHWITH
--243 days credit for time already served given
--Payment of Statutory Costs of Counts #1 and #4 are to be paid as a condition of Extended Supervison for Cases 15CF237 and 15CF271.
The Court orders the Defendant to report to the Jefferson County Sheriff's Office today for DNA sample provision.

As to Case 15CF237, Count #1: 
The Court sentences Mr. Jackson  to a term of Imprisonment consistining of a term of Initial Confinement of 2 1/2 years and a term of Extended Supervision of 3 years. This sentence is to be served concurrent to all other sentences in Case 15CF237, but consecutive to sentences in Cases 15CF271 and 18CF14. Terms of Extended Supervision are to be those that were previously ordered as conditions of Probation. 

As to Case 15CF237, Count #2: 
The Court sentences Mr. Jackson  to a term of Imprisonment consistining of a term of Initial Confinement of 18 months and a term of Extended Supervision of 2 years. This sentence is to be served concurrent to all other sentences in Case 15CF237, but consecutive to sentences in Cases 15CF271 and 18CF14. Terms of Extended Supervision are to be those that were previously ordered as conditions of Probation. 

As to Case 15CF237, Count #3: 
The Court sentences Mr. Jackson  to a term of Imprisonment consistining of a term of Initial Confinement of 18 months and a term of Extended Supervision of 2 years. This sentence is to be served concurrent to all other sentences in Case 15CF237, but consecutive to sentences in Cases 15CF271 and 18CF14. Terms of Extended Supervision are to be those that were previously ordered as conditions of Probation. 

As to Case 15CF237, Count #5: 
The Court sentences Mr. Jackson  to a term of Imprisonment consistining of a term of Initial Confinement of 6 months and a term of Extended Supervision of 5 months. This sentence is to be served concurrent to all other sentences in Case 15CF237, but consecutive to sentences in Cases 15CF271 and 18CF14. Terms of Extended Supervision are to be those that were previously ordered as conditions of Probation. 

As to Case 15CF271, Count #9: 
The Court sentences Mr. Jackson  to a term of Imprisonment consistining of a term of Initial Confinement of 1 year and a term of Extended Supervision of 1 year. This sentence is to be served concurrent to sentence in Count #10 of Case 15CF271 , but consecutive to sentences in Cases 15CF237 and 18CF14. Terms of Extended Supervision are to be those that were previously ordered as conditions of Probation.  


 As to Case 15CF271, Count #10: 
The Court sentences Mr. Jackson  to a term of Imprisonment consistining of a term of Initial Confinement of 1 year and a term of Extended Supervision of 1 year. This sentence is to be served concurrent to sentence in Count #9 of Case 15CF271 , but consecutive to sentences in Cases 15CF237 and 18CF14. Terms of Extended Supervision are to be those that were previously ordered as conditions of Probation.  


Parties will submit a stipulation as to sentece credit re: Cases 15CF271 and 15CF237, it is to be applied to Case 15CF237; if no agreement can be reached a hearing is to be scheduled. 
recess: 3:39pm
Sentencing hearing on revocation on September 6, 2018 at 02:30 pm.

Cases 15CF237, 15CM147, 15CM253, 15CF271 and 15CM219 called together at 2:39pm [mo]

Defendant Quinard M Jackson in court, in custody with Attorney John Vernon Rhiel.   ADA Brookellen Teuber appears for the State of Wisconsin.
ADA Teuber verifies victim rights compliance

Sentencing Arguments given by Counsel
Statement made by Mr. Jackson

Upon direction of the Court, the Clerk contacts the Child Support Agency to inquire of Mr. Jackson's current child support payment status
Atty. Antholine appears in the Courtroom at 3:41pm
With permission of Mr. Jackson, the Court questions Atty. Antholine as to case 14FA113
Atty. Antholine exits the Courtroom at 3:45pm


As to Case 15CM219, the Court sentences the Defendant to:
--serve 135 days in the County Jail, WITHOUT Huber, this sentence is to commence FORTHWITH
--pay court costs plus $33 in subpoena fees, to be converted to Civil Judgement


As to Case 15CF271, Count #1  the Court sentences Defendant to:
--serve 1 year in Jefferson County Jail, WITHOUT Huber privileges; to be served consecutive to the sentence in 15CM219
--pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge plus $100 Domestic Abuse Surcharge= $618,  to be converted to Civil Judgement

As to Case 15CF271, Counts #9 and #10, the Court withholds sentence and places the Defendant on Probation for a term of 3 years 


As to Case 15CF237, Counts #1, #2, and #3, with Court withholds sentence and places the Defendant on Probation for a term on 5 years


As to Case 15CF237, Count #5, the Court withholds sentence and places the Defendant on Probation for a term of 2 years

Probation Conditions as to Counts 9 and 10 in Case 15CF271 and 15CF237:
--Certified Batterers' Treatment and Intervention Programming and follow through with treatment recommendations
--any other assessment, treatment or counseling per Agent
--No Contact with: Shantavia Armstrong, unless approved by DOC Agent and JCHS
--no acts or threats of violence
--no possession or ingestion of alcohol
--no presence in bars, taverns, or liquor stores
--No contact with any of Shatavia Armstrong's children, unless approved by Ms. Armstrong, Human Services, DOC Agent, Case Manager and GAL(if under CHIPS order)
--no possession of any dangerous weapons or ammunition
--As to Case 15CF271, Count #9: to pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge
--As to Case 15CF271, Count #10:to pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge
--to pay subpoena fees in the amount of $205
--As to Case 15CF237, Count #1:to pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge
--As to Case 15CF237,Count #2:to pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge
--As to Case 15CF237,Count #3:to pay costs of $268 plus $250 DNA surcharge
--As to Case 15CF237,Count #5: to pay costs of $243 plus $200 DNA surcharge


The Court determines that Mr. Jackson has already provided a DNA sample and does not order another
The Court will determine sentence credit on a later date.

Cases 15CF237, 15CF271, 15CM147, 15CM219 & 15CM253 called together at 4:05 pm [Clerk SH]
Defendant Quinard M Jackson in court, in-custody, with Attorney John Vernon Rhiel. ADA Brookellen Teuber appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

15CM219:
Constitutional rights given; plea of "No Contest" entered; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the plea, finds Defendant guilty, and orders JOC entered.
On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses Cases 15CM147 & 15CM253, jeopardy attaches and further prosecution is barred

15CF237: 
On Motion of the State, the Court strikes weapon enhancer on Counts #2 & #3

Constitutional rights given; plea of "No Contest" entered on Counts #1, #2, #3 & #5; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the plea, finds Defendant guilty, and orders JOC entered.
On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses all remaining counts, further prosecution is barred and jeopardy attaches

Court informs parties that given the latesness of the day, It will arrange for a sentencing date to allow parties full opportunity to arguments

Cases 15CF271, 15CM147, 15CM253, 15CF237, and 15CM219 called together at 10:30am [mo]
Defendant Quinard M Jackson in court, in custody with Attorney John Vernon Rhiel.   ADA Brookellen Teuber appears for the State of Wisconsin.

Atty. Rhiel indicates that he has had discussion with the State, global resolution is a possibility
